categories.name: Kashmir Shaivism 36 Tattvas Advanced
categories.description: Advanced mastery of the 36 Tattvas: structure, function, and sādhanā implications across pure (śuddha) and manifest layers.

subcategories.name: Śuddha Tattvas (1–5)
subcategories.description: The five pure principles: Śiva, Śakti, Sadāśiva, Īśvara, and Śuddhavidyā.

subcategories.name: From Māyā to Pṛthvī (6–36)
subcategories.description: Māyā, the five kañcukas, puruṣa–prakṛti, antaḥkaraṇa, indriyas, tanmātras, and mahābhūtas.

questions.question: Which tattva denotes unmoving, attribute-free awareness?
questions.explanation: Śiva tattva is pure consciousness (cit) beyond subject–object; all other tattvas unfold from this base.

questions.question: Which tattva is the dynamic power inseparable from Śiva?
questions.explanation: Śakti is the vibratory creative potency of consciousness, the capacity whereby the One appears as many.

questions.question: In Sadāśiva tattva, which pole dominates—'I' (aham) or 'this' (idam)?
questions.correctAnswer: Aham predominates with a faint idam
questions.explanation: Sadāśiva is aham-idam where the I-sense eclipses objectivity; revelation is 'I am this'.

questions.question: Which tattva utters 'idam aham'—emphasising revelation of the object?
questions.explanation: Īśvara tattva highlights the object as a manifestation of the Self, with idam more vivid than aham.

questions.question: Which tattva reconciles I-ness and this-ness in balanced knowing?
questions.explanation: Śuddhavidyā (pure knowledge) harmonises subject and object in a balanced cognition free from limitation.

questions.question: Name the five śuddha tattvas in order from highest.
questions.explanation: The pure pentad unfolds from still awareness to dynamic knowing, forming the transcendental tier.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva is most associated with free will (svātantrya) as creative display?
questions.explanation: Śakti embodies svātantrya—the absolute freedom of consciousness to vibrate, conceal, reveal, and manifest.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva is linked to the mantra-state of 'aham'?
questions.explanation: Sadāśiva’s mantra is aham; the I shines forth while the this (idam) is latent.

questions.question: Which tattva is connected with the perfect grace of revelation (anugraha)?
questions.explanation: Īśvara emphasises the revelatory grace whereby the Self presents the world as its own display.

questions.question: Which tattva is the locus of pure measuring (māna) without limitation?
questions.explanation: Śuddhavidyā is pure discernment, measurement untainted by the limiting veils introduced later.

questions.question: What do the śuddha tattvas lack that appears from Māyā onward?
questions.explanation: The pure pentad is free of contraction; Māyā brings veiling and the five limiting cloaks (kañcukas).

questions.question: Which two tattvas are an inseparable unity called Paramaśiva?
questions.explanation: Paramaśiva denotes Śiva-Śakti nonduality—awareness and its power never truly separate.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva corresponds to the seed of language as divine articulation?
questions.explanation: Īśvara correlates with the articulated revelation of objects as the Self’s speech (vāg-vimarśa).

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva best maps to the experience of nonconceptual, luminous silence?
questions.explanation: Śiva tattva is sheer luminosity absent mental movement; silence that contains all potentials.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva marks the first shimmer of differentiation without real division?
questions.explanation: Sadāśiva is the primordial hint of manifestation where unity gently tilts toward relation.

questions.question: Which tattva provides the metaphysical ground for pure knowledge (jñāna) unbound by ignorance?
questions.explanation: Śuddhavidyā is pure knowledge itself, not yet narrowed by Māyā’s limiting measures.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva is most explicitly associated with spanda doctrine?
questions.explanation: Spanda (subtle vibration) names Śakti’s creative throb through which appearance arises.

questions.question: Arrange Sadāśiva, Śuddhavidyā, Īśvara by increasing object emphasis.
questions.explanation: From I-dominant to balanced to object-dominant reflects increasing clarity of the 'this'.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva is linked to pure I-consciousness witnessing its own radiance?
questions.explanation: Sadāśiva is the contemplative I that intuits the world as itself without solidifying it.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva most closely grounds the possibility of mantra and śabda?
questions.explanation: As revelation of 'this', Īśvara grounds expressive articulation that later becomes language.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva corresponds to pure capacity-to-do before limitation of agency appears?
questions.explanation: Śakti is unrestricted capacity (kriyā-śakti) antecedent to the later cloak of kalā limiting agency.

questions.question: What term captures the undivided unity of knowledge and action in the pure tier?
questions.explanation: Vimarśa is consciousness’s reflexive self-apprehension uniting knowing and doing as one.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva is beyond even the notions of freedom and bondage?
questions.explanation: Śiva is prior to all predicates; freedom and bondage arise only with manifest polarity.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva ensures that the world, when seen rightly, is nothing but the Self?
questions.explanation: In Śuddhavidyā, measurement itself reveals unity, not division—seeing the world as the Self.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva correlates with unimpeded icchā (will) as divine longing-to-manifest?
questions.explanation: Śakti embodies icchā, jñāna, and kriyā in perfect freedom before Māyā differentiates them.

questions.question: Which tattva marks the threshold before Māyā introduces constriction?
questions.explanation: Śuddhavidyā is the final pure rung; beyond it, Māyā inaugurates limitation.

questions.question: In practice, contemplating which tattva dissolves subject–object fixation most directly?
questions.explanation: Resting as Śiva dismantles dual fixation by recognising awareness as the sole reality.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva is most aligned with the bhāva 'I am all this'?
questions.explanation: The Īśvara stance affirms the cosmos as the Lord’s own body—'this' shines as Self.

questions.question: Which śuddha tattva fits the statement 'balanced recognition of I and this'?
questions.explanation: Śuddhavidyā establishes equipoise—knowledge that neither eclipses I nor object.

questions.question: What does Māyā introduce into limitless consciousness?
questions.explanation: Māyā veils the infinite, imposing measures that enable the experience of finite multiplicity.

questions.question: List the five kañcukas (limiting cloaks).
questions.explanation: The kañcukas contract doership, knowing, longing, temporality, and situational order.

questions.question: Which kañcuka limits authorship/doership?
questions.explanation: Kalā truncates unlimited kriyā-śakti into finite capacity, producing a sense of 'I can only do so much'.

questions.question: Which kañcuka imposes partial knowledge?
questions.explanation: Vidyā limits omniscience into fragmentary knowing, creating subject–object epistemic gaps.

questions.question: Which kañcuka is experienced as attachment or lack prompting seeking?
questions.explanation: Rāga contracts fullness into craving; one seeks completion in objects and states.

questions.question: Which kañcuka creates temporality—before/after?
questions.explanation: Kāla slices eternity into sequences, enabling karma and memory to operate.

questions.question: Which kañcuka binds one to specific circumstances and laws?
questions.explanation: Niyati binds the jīva to a determinate order—place, pattern, and causal constraints.

questions.question: Which tattva follows the kañcukas in the standard 36-tattva list?
questions.explanation: Puruṣa is the limited subject who undergoes experience within the field structured by Māyā and the kañcukas.

questions.question: Which tattva pairs with Puruṣa as the material ground of manifestation?
questions.explanation: Prakṛti is primordial nature composed of sattva, rajas, tamas, serving as the field of evolutes.

questions.question: Order the antaḥkaraṇa from subtle to gross function: buddhi, ahaṃkāra, manas.
questions.explanation: Buddhi discerns, ahaṃkāra appropriates as 'I', and manas coordinates sensory data.

questions.question: Which inner instrument performs decisive knowledge (adhyavasāya)?
questions.explanation: Buddhi yields determinate judgments; it is the seat of clarity and discrimination.

questions.question: Which inner instrument fashions the sense of personal identity?
questions.explanation: Ahaṃkāra appropriates experiences to 'I', enabling egoic agency and ownership.

questions.question: Which inner instrument processes options and doubt (saṃśaya)?
questions.explanation: Manas attends, compares, and hesitates—manages inputs before buddhi decides.

questions.question: Name the five jñānendriyas (knowledge senses).
questions.explanation: These receive inputs from the world enabling cognition of qualities.

questions.question: Name the five karmendriyas (action organs).
questions.explanation: They carry out expression and activity: speaking, grasping, moving, eliminating, generating.

questions.question: Match tanmātra to quality: śabda, sparśa, rūpa, rasa, gandha.
questions.explanation: Tanmātras are subtle essences that seed the gross elements and their qualities.

questions.question: Which mahābhūta corresponds to space and supports sound?
questions.explanation: Ākāśa provides room for vibration; sound propagates there most directly.

questions.question: Which mahābhūta corresponds to movement and supports touch?
questions.explanation: Vāyu articulates motion and tactile sensation emerging from sparśa tanmātra.

questions.question: Which mahābhūta corresponds to heat/visibility and supports form?
questions.explanation: Tejas enables visibility and transformation; it correlates with rūpa tanmātra.

questions.question: Which mahābhūta corresponds to liquidity and supports taste?
questions.explanation: Ap conveys cohesion and taste; rasa is apprehended through liquid medium.

questions.question: Which mahābhūta corresponds to solidity and supports smell?
questions.explanation: Pṛthvī provides resistance and fragrance-bearing capacity; gandha is its quality.

questions.question: Which tattva marks the first truly 'impure' (aśuddha) layer in some enumerations?
questions.explanation: Some Trika lists count Māyā+kañcukas as pure-impure and start aśuddha with Puruṣa; others include Prakṛti onward.

questions.question: How do guṇas relate to experience under contraction?
questions.correctAnswer: They bias cognition and action via sattva, rajas, tamas
questions.explanation: Prakṛti’s guṇas flavour perception and behaviour, shaping karma within Māyā’s constraints.

questions.question: Which indriya pair links speech and hearing in expression–reception polarity?
questions.explanation: Vāk externalises thought while śrotra receives vibration; both are modulations of consciousness.

questions.question: Why are tanmātras called 'subtle'?
questions.correctAnswer: They are pre-gross essences not yet spatially extended
questions.explanation: They seed qualities without full extension; gross elements crystallise them into tangible forms.

questions.question: Which tattva serves as the pivot from transcendence to empirical mind?
questions.explanation: The antaḥkaraṇa translates cosmic contraction into a functional psyche for the jīva.

questions.question: Place these in correct order within the 36: tanmātras, karmendriyas, mahābhūtas.
questions.explanation: Standard evolute order moves from faculties to subtle essences to gross elements.

questions.question: What is the soteriological key to transcending kañcukas according to Trika?
questions.explanation: By recognising the Self as Śiva, the limiting cloaks fall away as appearances within awareness.

questions.question: Which practice aligns doership (kalā) back with unrestricted kriyā-śakti?
questions.explanation: When action is recognised as Śakti’s play, agency is no longer felt as limited 'mine'.

questions.question: Which tattva completes the cascade as tangible solidity in space?
questions.explanation: Pṛthvī concludes manifestation as gross earth—maximal contraction of the prior subtleties.
